title: So over the last few years, Riot has been trying to give counterplay to all new champs and reworks
body:
Slowly turning targetted abilities into skillshots on many mages, or introducing windows of vulnerability or downtime on other skills (i.e. making veigar's stun not instant anymore), and have even outright removed mechanics from champions for the sake of counterplay (i.e. kass and talon silences)

Now we're in a situation where ADCs are the only class who's main damage has no counterplay, and are being defended by champions who also have no counterplay either; you just instantly shield/heal allies and they get to keep rightclicking you with guaranteed/ranged damage

It's no surprise we've come to this

How could Riot add counterplay to autoattacks without making the game cunklier for everyone?

I don't think counterplay needs to be added to autoattacks, specifically, right now the issue is that like 80% of a marksman's entire power is placed on their autoattacks, with little to no skill-based variation. On top of that, marksmen also tend to have steroids that are very reliable, on-demand self-peel / CC / mobility, and only a few abilities that require aiming or planning. Shifting a lot of their power to be a lot more conditional (e.g. putting a marksman at only a fraction of their current power if they just right-click, but giving them massive boosts in power when they satisfy difficult and interactive conditions) could help give counterplay to the class without necessarily making their autoattacks clunkier.

I agree with this. I think Jhin is one of the best designed marskmen since there's a clear window of vulnerability and you can somewhat play around his autoattacks (i.e., you know that when he's got his 4th shot prepared he's going to hit like a truck).

So.....say they shift some of Twitch's power from his autos to his E, making it to where his E and poison are more reliable than his autos?

Is that what you're thinking?

Not more reliable, but more powerful certainly, so that simply right-clicking won't be as strong, but actually sticking onto a target for long enough and interacting with them gets you more power. Something as simple as uncapping Twitch's poison stacks could help him significantly in this respect, for example, as it would reward him more for a sustained autoattack pattern, and could help move some power away from his current front-loaded burst (such as by removing the bonus AD on his ult, or making the bonus attack speed on his Q more conditional).

The only way they could is if AAs became skillshots. But that only really works in SMITE because of its third person perspective. 

Jhin, Graves and Kalista are the only exceptions because Jhin and Graves' autos have a cooldown (through reloading) and Kalista's AAs will miss if the targets are removed from her vision.

Quick idea hash for auto attack counterplay.

{{champion:22}} Autos can't crit or deal much damage until she amps up her Q, and only can use it on targets slowed by her (basically what she has right now, more or less).

{{champion:51}} Caitlyn's autos are slow, telegraphed, and have a noticeable wind-up time. However, they deal hefty damage, maybe even have it where she can only have homing bullets to a certain range. After that her autos are fast skillshots. Traps will let her auto without the wind-up time, or home in as long as they are revealed.

{{champion:42}} He's already ability based, maybe put his machine gun on his autos, but treat them like Lulu's passive where it is scaling damage with ratios and on-hits and crits apply only at the initial auto. The longer Corki stays in range with his autos the more damage he can pepper on his opponents, but he has to decide to either stay at range and use missiles or to get up close for max damage.

{{champion:119}} This guy is almost perfect already. Except make it so that Draven's auto attacks depend on his axes, that becomes his Q passive where he gains charges of axes, and the active of his Q impales his target with an axe (skillshot), and auto attacking them again gives a boost of some kind. If Draven drops his axes, he is stuck at one axe and cannot auto until it returns to him or he drops it.

{{champion:81}} This guy is already fine, just remove his ability to abuse every on-hit in the game. Make his Q apply only to one on-hit at a time or something.

{{champion:104}} Ironically the most balanced. Maybe work on giving his W some depth.

{{champion:222}} Mini-gun range reduced, rockets made much slower and powerful. Increase mana cost on rockets, make them deal more damage with crit but remove their ability to create AoE crits. That's just disgusting.

{{champion:202}} Remove the movement speed on crits. Make his traps something that can be active immediately but if left for some time, can ramp up to be devastating. This is to give him kiting potential without being The Fast.

{{champion:429}} Remove passive hop. That's just plain dumb. Instead, give her Q a lower cooldown where she can hop away more often, but the damage is reduced. If she hops forward the spear damage is increased. This fits her fantasy as a pursuer and makes sense in terms of force and direction. Have a large portion of her auto attack damage be translated into damage for Rend. Also make her passive/ult interaction consentual and give it more options.

{{champion:203}} Make Lamb and Wolf feel like separate entities, like having Lamb thrive in duels and kiting while Wolf thrives in chases and seeking out prey. Perhaps if an opponent runs and you have a mark on them, wolf chases and you can follow him? Or perhaps you can switch between lamb and wolf, each having a separate HP bar that if depleted, puts their respawn on a high cooldown that resets if you die or shortens when you collect a mark.

{{champion:96}} Make him Kog in Invasion. Long charge-up period with a visual warning, then straight-up turret mode. It rewards strategy and placing teamfights well. Also perhaps make Kog stand still and the range be shown as your focus becomes selecting targets, maybe even allow casting ult during this period of time.

{{champion:236}} Each gun has a cooldown. Double-tap is excluded from this. You can now cast each ability twice in rapid succession (except dash), and you choose whether to blow all your damage at once or save it. Ultimate could have a thing where Lucian does his one-directional cast but you choose how long the ult goes for. It will go on forever, draining mana and locking you out of all spells except dash. If you really want to go all-in with this, make Lucian hit R for every shot he wants to shoot during his ult.

{{champion:21}} Utilize dual guns theme in a different way than Lucian. Q now shoots two bullets, and if the first one crits the second one bounces to the nearest target, prioritizing champions. Make It Rain (E) now increases the damage of MF's bullets (abilities and autos) depending on how long you were in it, but radius is increased immensely. MF ult now deals significantly less damage to account for E changes.

I'm just saying, but there's more to counterplay than dodging. Hell, that's a part of strategy, having to deal with something reliable, and play around it through some means. Can't dodge a bullet, so find a way to not be in the path, or stop the bullet from being fired in the first place. I'm not saying that ADCs aren't too strong, that's not my point. 

My point is that things can have counterplay outside dodging with your pro-reflexes. Hell, that was a main complaint about a year ago, that strategy was being removed and replaced by reaction-fests. Counterplay to ADCs is proper positioning and protection of your own carries as a fight thunders on. Divers try to get behind enemy lines, tanks try to stop that, ADC's fire away, while mages make picks. 

Disclaimer: Like said, not saying that ADCs aren't too strong, but having reliable ways of doing damage isn't without counterplay. In MMO fights, there is damage you can't avoid, but through Healers efforts, you can get through them with minimal effect.

Not completely true. AAs draw minion aggro(really only relevant in lane-phase), and there are a lot of itemization options that actually work really well vs. AA damage.

And I want to get this out of the way now before I move on, I think anti-AA itemization is actually really good. 20% off crits, 10% off AAs in general, AS slow, GW application and reflect damage. You CAN drasticly reduce damage you take from AAs if you want.

Two problems

First problem is ADCs are reaching their lategame at two items. IE+Shiv is currently giving ADCs everything they used to require 4 items for. AD,AS,Crit,Waveclear,sustain (Warlords, and Ardent if present), and even the ability to deal reasonable damage through armor thanks to Shiv damage.

Second, itemizing against AA damage is only effective when you just dedicate your build towards it from the get-go. If you get a damage item first, or need to get MR, or need to get tenacity, or even just get a jungle item first, then your defense falls behind the damage curve.



Personally, I think Warlords was the tipping point. Sustain is really powerful, and granting access to substantial sustain from the get-go that scales with other items immediately erases one of the usual weaknesses that used to be present until later in the match.

Compare defensive reductions to %hp damage and % armor pen, then consider as well the damage returns per offensive stat for ADCs.  You can't drastically reduce damage from AAs if they build a tank buster build path.
